Title: Account Structure
Context: We have proposed multiple Account Structure for the AWS Landing Zone
Decision: Lendscape decided to go with the Vertical Account Structure with HMS Decoupled
Negative Consequences:
1.	Lack of Isolation
2.	Lack of Customization
3.	Limited Scalability
4.	Customer Impact

Title: IP CIDR Structure
Context: Choose IP CIDR to be used for the HMS Client Infrastructure
Decision: Pending decision from Lendscape to provide the CIDR ranges

Title: Ingress
Context: We have proposed a Centralised or Distributed Edge to implement for the architecture
Decision: Lendscape preferred Centralised Edge for now due to cost of maintaining full Distributed

Title: EC2 Sizes per Tier
Context: We have created a reference architecture showing sizes of instances per Tier. This is based on Assess Analysis Document shared during initial phases, plus knowledge of Lendscape architecture
Decision: Lendscape noted of the similarity between Tier 3 and Tier 2 sizing and cost

Title: AWS Managed Microsoft AD for OS authentication
Context: Lendscape requires to have an Active Directory for server domain join and OS authentication in AWS. They have an existing AD that they use on premise, and an Azure AD.
Decision:
* Lendscape wanted to have a new Active Directory to use in AWS. Currently, we plan to use this AD as standalone and no integration or connection to other AD. But in the future, there might have plans to establish forest trust in the On-premise AD.
* The AWS Managed AD will be provisioned in a central AWS account (Shared services account) and will be shared to the other AWS accounts in Lendscape's LZ
Positive Consequences:
* Easy to setup as it is a managed service and less operational overhead.
* Ready for integration to on-premise AD
* Highly available setup
Negative Consequences:
* More costly than the traditional Microsoft AD servers.
* Limited customization. Depending on the use case, the AWS Managed AD offers less flexibility than the traditional Microsoft AD servers.

Title: EC2 for instances and database
Context: Due to limitations due to short delivery times, for the pilot phase, we will focus on testing that the workloads work on AWS on the designed basic infrastructure.
Decision: A "lift & shift" without block-replication will be done with test data on empty EC2 instances with Windows and Windows SQL Server.
Positive Consequences:
* Easy to setup.
* Ready for integration to on-premise AD
* This will allow Cloud Bridge to shadow building and installation process
Negative Consequences: * We will not be testing the linux re-platforming

Title: Building and Installation of software
Context: Cloud Bridge has conducted an analysis and basic migration from powershell to bash scripting, but lot of details are unknown for Cloud Bridge in order to automate the process
Decision: Cloud Bridge will shadow Lendscape tech team during the building and installation in AWS EC2 instances (Windows) of the software
Positive Consequences:
* Quickest way to have a pilot working
* Knowledge transfer
Negative Consequences: * Success of pilot phase depends on customer availability.

Title: Nginx on EC2 instances
Context: Due to limitations due to short delivery times, for the pilot phase, we will focus on testing that the workloads work on AWS on the designed basic infrastructure.
Decision: Cloud Bridge will build empty linux boxes with nginx and customer will configure them
Positive Consequences:
* Quickest way to have a pilot working
* Knowledge transfer
Negative Consequences: * Nginx features are not fully supported just by using ALB, so we need to find the right combination of AWS Services

Title: RDS Custom to be applied after pilot phase
Context: DSP has recommended this approach for DB in order to be able to support in RDS PostgreSQL, all the features customer requires from SQL Server. Updated: At the moment, Lendscape is not going to implement RDS Custom
Decision: Decision rejected at the moment as Lendscape is progressing on using current SQL Server clusters on EC2
Positive Consequences: * In theory, RDS Custom will implement everything required
Negative Consequences:
* We don’t have expertise on RDS Custom
* Features/Limitations unknown

Title: HA for SQL Servers
Context: Lendscape currently doesn’t have HA at the DB layer
Decision: Lendscape wants Cloud Bridge to set up an Always On HA SQL Cluster. Cloud Bridge can only offer help and some AWS official guides, so Lendscape will do the work with CB assitance
Negative Consequences:
* CB not experts at SQL Server
* Work to be discarded if we move to RDS Custom

Title: Pilot scope in terms of system outputs
Context: Definition of what is the customer type to be onboarded and what the application should contain
Decision: Justin has proposed to have dummy data on the pilot infrastructure and application and then perform a security analysis before on board an actual customer
Positive Consequences:
* Easy to setup.
* Ready for integration to on-premise AD
* Security posture improved from the beginning

Title: Pilot Tier
Context: There are three possible tiers to implement. Tier 1 and Tier 3 are very different in terms of infrastructure
Decision: Cloud Bridge will implement Tier 1 solution for the POC delivery
Positive Consequences: * Focusing on proving workload working on AWS
Negative Consequences: * We will need to deploy Tier 3 after the pilot phase as top priority to have a feeling of network cost

Title: Typo Mistake
Context: During the creation of the accounts for the 0000poc customer, the testing account (1 of 3) was named wrongly as Client 0123
Decision: Ivor checked client list and opted for just keep working as it's as they don't have this customer with them anymore
Positive Consequences: Cloud Bridge has not to remove/rename it saving time
Negative Consequences: AFT Module has a tech debt for removing and renaming accounts as it is not a simple task - This will need to be explained in a runbook way in the future

Title: AWS Managed Microsoft AD for OS authentication
Context: Lendscape requires to have an Active Directory for server domain join and OS authentication in AWS. The AWS-managed AD will be used across possibly 50+ client accounts of Lendscape it will also be used cross-region.
Decision: To use standard edition AWS Directory Service for Microsoft Active Directory in a central account that will be shared to other account without the use of directory sharing.
Positive Consequences: * The directory will be shared to other accounts via the transit gateway network with the right security group rules. Directory service sharing to other account has a per hour and per account cost so we won't have to perform this to other accounts. This will be a cheaper cost as we can offset the per hour and per account hourly cost.
Negative Consequences:
* Cross-region AD feature is not available in the Standard edition. Will have to find a workaround to be able to connect the servers in another region
* Need to create a custom automation script to join/unjoin instances to the domain.

Title: POC Implementation for AppStream in Tier1
Context: Landscape wants to implement a remote desktop solution so they can install the javabased swing client to be offerted to their customer
Decision: Basic infrastructure has been designed by Cloud Bridge as a initial proposal and accepted to be evolved in babysteps by Lendscape
Positive Consequences: * Simple implementation and easy to enable and disable in terraform
Negative Consequences: * Lendscape doesn't have experience in all the services involved in this solution

Title: POC Implementation for AppStream in Tier1
Context: Fleet instances will be deployed in the app subnet
Decision: this needs to be confirmed with Lendscape
Positive Consequences: Fleet instances will be deployed in the app subnet
Negative Consequences: * Instances won't be exposed to the Internet
column10: * Posibility of running out-of-IPs in the App VPC?

Title: Use of Amazon FSx for Windows for SQL FCI
Context: Lendscape will need a file share to use for SQL FCI File-share witness. Amazon FSx for windows is commonly used as file-share witness when forming SQL FCI.
Decision: To use Amazon FSx for Windows with Multi-AZ as file-share witness in SQL FCI
Positive Consequences:
* FSx for Windows is a managed service and Lendscape won't have to maintain a server. It's easy to use and mount ready for the EC2 Windows instances.
* Offer multi-AZ option which offers higher availability for the file share
Negative Consequences: * Costly compared to EC2 alternatives, which is normal for AWS Managed services.

Title: Use of Amazon FSx for Netapp for SQL FCI
Context: Lendscape will need a file share to use for SQL FCI File-share witness. Lendscape found the Amazon FSx for Windows costly for the Multi-AZ setup, so they went for the cheaper option of Amazon FSx. They also have a base latency requirements for the file share performance.
Decision: To use Amazon FSx for Netapp Ontap with Multi-AZ as file-share witness in SQL FCI
Positive Consequences: * FSx for Netapp Ontap performs better and cheaper than the Windows option
Negative Consequences: * A bit complex to use with the Storage virtual machines and volumes mounting and maintenance, compared to Amazon FSx for Windows.

Title: Nginx as a Shared Resource
Context: Due to cost considerations from Nginx Plus in AWS marketplace, Lendscape has considered to move the Nginx / DMZ infrastructure from a distributed approach for T1 and T2 clients, and to shared resource for T3 clients, into a full complete shared resource used by all client base.
Decision: To move Nginx and DMZ into a shared resource infrastructure within Network account
Positive Consequences: * To achieve, cost savings for the Nginx usage will higher vs. the distributed approach. This will also be similar to current onpremise implementation.
Negative Consequences: * While accepting, Terraform code has to be updated, moving DMZ modules from client resource into ancillary. Planning of IP space, Configuration Management, routing, and strategy for resource exposure should also be planned.

Title: One AWS Account for each Domain
Context: A Domain in Lendscape space can be equivalent to PROD, TEST, or DR. This is similarly known as Environment names. Lendscape has their environments under each Domain to cover the multiple environment approach their client has, and to completely set the demarcation line between live and non-live resources.
Decision: To use one AWS account per Domain present for the onboarded clients
Positive Consequences: * To achieve, is a simpler and organized approach, and is not very far from the original Organization proposal by Cloud Bridge. It imposes complete control and governance for each Domain.
Negative Consequences: * While accepting, it is to be noted that Domains are not to be confused with Environments. Furthermore, higher environment like pre-prod is considered a part of PROD domain due to likelyness to production as opposed to being part of TEST domain being it non-live.

Title: Keep Network Architecture for APAC
Context: APAC region as of Feb-24 will only be moving 2 T3 clients into AWS space, engaging with the question of whether it is economical or practical to keep the architecture the same as in EMEA.
Decision: To keep APAC networking the same as EMEA, meaning no changes will be applied from networking perspective to impose scale-down regardless of clients moving into it.
Positive Consequences: * To achieve, a more similar regional presence will continue, simplifying admin and management from development and operational perspective.
Negative Consequences: * While accepting, motivations to reduce size further down the line can complicate set up and introduce additional effort to re-architecture for cost savings.

Title: Scale Down Management Layer for APAC
Context: APAC region as of Feb-24 will only be moving 2 T3 clients into AWS space, engaging with the question of whether it is economical or practical to keep the architecture the same as in EMEA.

Title: Cross Account Bucket Access
Context: A bucket has been requested to be created in CICD account that will be shared among client accounts for the purpose of holding FCR atifacts. To establish connectivity from client accounts to public S3 endpoint a network change / addition is required. This can be achieved by adding gateway endpoint directly to APP-VPC or create an Interface Endpoint we can allow on the Central Egress if traffic monitoring is utmost priority.
